data.title: Penny Mordaunt: Inside the real life of Tory rising star and PM hopeful
data.meta_description: From working as a magician's assistant to being forced to explain that Liz Truss was not 'hiding under a desk' when the then-prime minister didn't turn up to Parliament, we take a look back at Penny Mordaunt's life.
data.text:
Penny Mordaunt launches campaign video

Penny Mordaunt, who currently serves as Leader of the House of Commons, has put herself forward to become the next Tory leader and UK Prime Minister after Liz Truss sensationally quit after just 44 days in office.

But unlike other well-known potential candidates like Rishi Sunak, Ms Mordaunt is relatively unknown to the British public. Express Politics has put together a simple guide on everything you need to know about the Tory rising star as she launches her bid for Prime Minister.

READ MORE: Rishi Sunak is first contender to pass 100 Tory MP threshold

Who is Penny Mordaunt?

Ms Mordaunt is the MP for Portsmouth North and has represented the constituency since 2010. Serving as Minister for Trade Policy since 2021, she has held several cabinet positions in her time as a politician, including Minister for Defence, Minister for Equalities and as Paymaster General.

Born in Devon in 1973, Ms Mordaunt is the daughter of a former paratrooper and special needs teacher and has a twin brother.

She is distantly related to the late Angela Lansbury, who is her grandmother’s cousin, and she is therefore also distantly related to former Labour leader George Lansbury.

The family moved to Portsmouth, where she now serves as MP, when she was young and once recalled watching soldiers set off for the Falklands, saying: "It taught me that my country stands up to bullies."

When she was just 15, her mother died from breast cancer , leaving her to help bring up her siblings. Her father was also diagnosed with cancer the following year.

She told the Sunday Times in 2019: "It was pretty relentless in terms of stresses and losing a parent, you're trying to deal with all of that and study, run a house, look after two brothers."

She was married to Paul Murray, whom she met at university, but they divorced only one year after they wed in 1999. Ms Mordaunt was later in a relationship with classical singer Ian Lyon, whom she reportedly split from in 2016.

Unlike many MPs, Ms Mordaunt lives near her constituency in Portsmouth, on the South Coast of England. It is understood that she lives alone, though she has previously shared her feline companion ‘Moggs’ on her Instagram page.

Inside her education

Ms Mordaunt attended a state school in Hampshire and later studied drama at a theatre school.

The first member of her family to attend university studied philosophy at the University of Reading and graduated in 1995 with a 2:1.

During her student years, she was active in the political scene and was President of the Reading University Student’s Union.

Shortly after her studies ended, she became involved with the Conservative party.

Her employment history

Under John Major, she was president of Youth for the Conservative party and went on to work as head of broadcasting under party leader William Hague.

The party leader hopeful has a colourful employment background, having worked in a factory, as a magician's assistant, and in an orphanage in Romania.

She even worked as head of foreign press on former American President George W Bush’s 2000 campaign.

The now Portsmouth North MP first contested the seat in the 2005 general election, but despite securing a 5.5 percent swing, she lost out to Labour. She eventually won the seat in 2010, securing an 8.4 percent swing from Labour.

More recently, Ms Mordaunt has supported the 2016 leave campaign and is a Royal Navy Reserve.

Four fast facts on Penny Mordaunt

In 2014 gave a speech on "poultry welfare" after a dare by her navy training officers which involved saying "a particular word, the abbreviation of cockerel, several times during a speech on the floor".

She is a navy reservist and was appointed the UK's first-ever female defence secretary by Theresa May

Former Brexit minister Lord Frost once said that "sometimes I didn't even know where she was" during Brexit negotiations.

In 2014, she appeared on ITV competition show Splash! where she was mentored on diving by Tom Daley.

Inside her voting record

Penny Mordaunt, 49, has navigated plenty of political turmoil in the 12 years she's served as a Member of Parliament, seeing through four prime ministers. She remained in cabinet under Theresa May to make her support for Brexit felt and stayed away from controversy during Boris Johnson's scandal-ridden time in power.

But now it seems she thinks she's ready for her own turn in No 10, something Sir Keir Starmer joked about this week saying: "I guess under this Tory government, everybody gets to be prime minister for 15 minutes."

On transport: She has consistently voted for higher taxes on plane tickets and in favour of new high speed rail infrastructure, but voted against slowing the rise in rail fares and a publicly owned rail system.

On the environment: Ms Mordaunt has a mixed record on environmental issues, voting both for and against the use of fracking, though has "ghenerall voted against measures to prevent climate change" according to TheyWorkForYou, with 8 votes for and 21 votes against.

Her views on the NHS: She has "almost always voted for reforming the NHS so GPs buy services on behalf of their patients".

On defence: A Navy Reservist, she has a firm stance on foreign policy and military issues, voting in favour of the use of British armed forces and for replacing Trident with a new nuclear weapons system.

On education: She has consistently voted for university tuition fees, as well as for greater autonomy for schools.

Her views on home affairs: She has consistently supported mass surveillance of people’s communications and activities, for a stricter asylum system, and for stronger enforcement of immigration rules.

On taxes: Ms Mordaunt has "generally voted against a banker’s bonus tax" and against increasing the tax rate applied to income over £150,000, but voted for more restrictive regulation of trade union activity and for increasing the rate of VAT.

Her views on LGBT issues: She has consistently voted for equal gay rights but against laws to promote equality and human rights.

As equalities minister, she faced some fury over her views and comments regarding transgender communities. She later rowed back on her statements, saying: "If you've been in the Royal Navy, and you have competed physically against men, you understand the biological difference between men and women".
